introduction.p: If we know two angles and one side of a triangle, we can use the Law of Sines to solve the triangle. We can also use the Law of Sines when we know two sides and the angle opposite one of them. But the Law of Sines is not helpful for the problem that opened this chapter, finding the distance from Avery to Clio. In this case we know two sides of the triangle, a and c, and the included angle, B.
To solve a triangle when we know two sides and the included angle, we will need a generalization of the Pythagorean theorem known as the Law of Cosines.

The Pythagorean theorem is actually a special case of a more general law that applies to all triangles, no matter what the size of angle C. The equation relating the three sides of a triangle is c^{2} = a^{2} + b^{2} - 2ab \cos C You can see that when C is a right angle, \cos 90\degree = 0, so the equation reduces to the Pythagorean theorem.
We can write similar equations involving the angles or A or B. The three equations are all versions of the Law of Cosines.

assemblage.title: Law of Cosines
assemblage.p: If the angles of a triangle are A, B, and C, and the opposite sides are respectively a, b, and c, then

note.p: For a proof of the Law of Cosines, see Homework Problems 57 and 58.

sidebyside.p: Now we can solve the problem of the distance from Avery to Clio. Here is the figure from Section 3.1 showing the location of the three towns.

statement.p: How far is it from Avery to Clio?

sidebyside.p: The angle \angle ABC = 35\degree + 90\degree = 125\degree. Thus, in \triangle ABC we have a = 34,~ c = 48 and B = 125\degree. The distance from Avery to Clio is represented by b in the figure.

solution.p: We know two sides and the included angle, and we choose the version of the Law of Cosines that uses our known angle, B. \begin{align*} b^{2} \amp = a^{2} + c^{2} - 2ac \cos B \amp\amp \text{Substitute the known values.}\\ b^{2} \amp = 34^{2} + 48^{2} - 2(34)(48) \cos 125\degree \amp\amp \text{Simplify the right side.}\\ b^{2} \amp = 3460 - 3264 \cos 125\degree = 5332.153 \amp\amp \text{Take square roots.} \\ b \amp = 73.02 \\ \end{align*} Avery is about 73 miles from Clio.

warning.p: When simplifying the Law of Cosines, be careful to follow the order of operations. In the previous example, the right side of the equation b^{2} = 34^{2} + 48^{2} - 2(34)(48) \cos 125\degree has three terms, and simplifies to \begin{align*} b^{2} \amp = 1156 + 2304 - 3264 \cos 125\degree\\ b^{2} \amp = 3460 - 3264(-0.573567364 ...) \\ \end{align*} Note that 3264 is the coefficient of \cos 125\degree, so it would be incorrect to subtract 3264 from 3460. If you are using a graphing calculator, you can enter the right side of the equation exactly as it is written.

statement.p: In \triangle ABC, a = 11,~c = 23, and B = 87\degree. Find b, and round your answer to two decimal places.

subsection.title: Finding an Angle
subsection.p: We can also use the Law of Cosines to find an angle when we know all three sides of a triangle. Pay close attention to the algebraic steps used to solve the equation in the next example.

sidebyside.p: In the triangle at right, a = 6,~ b = 7, and c = 11. Find angle C.

solution.p: We choose the version of the Law of Cosines that uses angle C. \begin{align*} c^{2} \amp = a^{2} + b^{2} - 2ab \cos C \amp\amp \text{Substitute the known values.}\\ 11^{2} \amp = 6^{2} + 7^{2} - 2(6)(7) \cos C \amp\amp \text{Simplify each side.}\\ 121 \amp = 36 + 49 - 84 \cos C \amp\amp \text{Isolate the cosine term.}\\ 36 \amp = -84 \cos C \amp\amp \text{Solve for cos C.}\\ \dfrac{-3}{7} \amp = \cos C \amp\amp \text{Solve for C.}\\ C \amp = \cos^{-1} (\dfrac{-3}{7}) = 115.4\degree \\ \end{align*} Angle C is about 115.4\degree.

statement.p: In \triangle ABC, a = 5.3,~b = 4.7, and c = 6.1. Find angle B, and round your answer to two decimal places.

subsection.p: Once we have calculated one of the angles in a triangle, we can use either the Law of Sines or the Law of Cosines to find a second angle. Here is how we would use the Law of Sines to find angle A in the previous example.

Thus, A = \sin^{-1}(0.4928) = 29.5\degree. (We know that A is an acute angle because it is opposite the shortest side of the triangle.) Finally, B = 180\degree - (A + C) \approx 35.1\degree Alternatively, we can use the Law of Cosines to find angle A. \begin{align*} a^{2} \amp = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc \cos A \amp\amp \text{Substitute the known values.}\\ 6^{2} \amp = 7^{2} + 11^{2} - 2(7)(11) \cos A \amp\amp \text{Simplify each side.}\\ 36 \amp = 49 + 121 - 154 \cos A \amp\amp \text{Isolate the cosine term.}\\ -134 \amp = -154 \cos A \amp\amp \text{Solve for} \cos A.\\ \dfrac{67}{77} \amp = \cos A \amp\amp \text{Solve for A.}\\ A \amp = \cos^{-1} (\dfrac{67}{77}) = 29.5\degree \\ \end{align*}

note.p: Using the Law of Sines requires fewer calculations than the Law of Cosines, but the Law of Cosines uses only the original values, instead of the results of our previous calculations and approximations.

Whenever we round off a number, we introduce inaccuracy into the calculations, and these inaccuracies grow with each additional calculation. Thus, for the sake of accuracy, it is best to use given values in preference to calculated values whenever possible.

subsection.title: Using the Law of Cosines for the Ambiguous Case
subsection.p: In Section 3.2 we encountered the ambiguous case:

If we know two sides a and b of a triangle and the acute angle \alpha opposite one of them, there may be one solution, two solutions, or no solution, depending on the size of a in relation to b and \alpha, as shown below.

ol.li: No solution: a \lt b \sin \alpha triangle \alpha is too short to make a triangle.
One solution: a = b \sin \alpha triangle \alpha is exactly the right length to make a right triangle
Two solutions: b \sin \alpha \lt a \lt b triangle
One solution: a \gt b triangle

subsection.p: If \alpha is an obtuse angle, things are simpler: there is one solution if a \gt b, and no solution if a \le b.

Because there are always two angles with a given sine, if we use the Law of Sines for the ambiguous case, we must check whether both possible angles result in a triangle. But here is another approach: We can apply the Law of Cosines to find the third side first. With that method, we'll need the quadratic formula.

assemblage.title: Quadratic Formula
assemblage.p: The solutions of the quadratic equation ax^{2} + bx + c = 0,~~a \not= 0, are given by x = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}

subsection.p: A quadratic equation can have one solution, two solutions, or no solution, depending on the value of the discriminant, b^{2} - 4ac. If we use the Law of Cosines to find a side in the ambiguous case, the quadratic formula will tell us how many triangles have the given properties.

ul.li: If the quadratic equation has one positive solutions, there is one triangle.
If the quadratic equation has two positive solutions, there are two triangles.
If the quadratic equation has no positive solutions, there is no triangle with the given properties.

statement.p: In \triangle ABC,~ B = 14.4\degree,~ a = 8, and b = 3. Solve the triangle.

solution.p: We begin by finding the third side of the triangle. Using the Law of Cosines, we have

Because there are two positive solutions for side c, either c = 5.503 or c = 9.994, there are two triangles with the given properties. We apply the Law of Cosines again to find angle C in each triangle.
For the triangle with c = 5.503, we have
and A = 180\degree - (14.4\degree + 27.1\degree) = 138.5\degree.
For the triangle with c = 9.994, we have
and A = 180\degree - (14.4\degree + 124.1\degree) = 41.5\degree. Both triangles are shown below.

note.p: In the previous example, notice that we used the Law of Cosines instead of the Law of Sines to find a second angle in the triangle, because there is only one angle between 0\degree and 180\degree with a given cosine. We don't have to check the results, as we would if we used the Law of Sines.

statement.p: Use the Law of Cosines to find all triangles ABC with A = 48\degree,~ a = 10, and b = 15.

subsection.title: Navigation
subsection.p: Even with the aid of GPS (Global Positioning System) instruments, aircraft pilots and ship captains need to understand navigation based on trigonometry.

statement.p: The sailing club leaves the marina on a heading 15\degree east of north and sails for 18 miles. They then change course, and after traveling for 12 miles on a heading 35\degree east of north, they experience engine trouble and radio for help. The marina sends a speed boat to rescue them. How far should the speed boat go, and on what heading?

sidebyside.p: We'd like to find the distance x and the angle \theta shown in the figure. In \triangle ABC, we can calculate the angle at point B where the sailing club changed course: B = 180\degree - 35\degree+ 15\degree = 160\degree We know a = 12 and c = 18. We use the Law of Cosines to find b and \angle A.

solution.p: Next, we apply the Law of Cosines again to find \angle A.
Thus, x = 29.56 and \theta = 8\degree + 15\degree = 23\degree. The speed boat should travel 29.56 miles on a heading 23\degree east of north.

sidebyside.p: Howard wants to fly from Anchorage to Nome, Alaska, a distance of 540 miles on a heading 57\degree west of north. After flying for some time, he discovers that his heading is in error, and he is actually flying 47\degree west of north. Howard corrects his flight plan and changes course when he is exactly 200 miles from Anchorage. What is his new heading, and how far is he from Nome?

subsection.title: Which Law to Use
subsection.p: How can we decide which law, the Law of Sines or the Law of Cosines, is appropriate for a given problem?

ul.li: If we are solving a right triangle, we don't need the Laws of Sines and Cosines; all we need are the definitions of the trigonometric ratios.
But for oblique triangles, we can identify the following cases:

assemblage.title: How to Solve an Oblique Triangle

row.cell: 1. Law of Sines, to find another side

cell.line: 2. Two side and the angle opposite
2. Law of Sines, to find another angle,
or Law of Cosines, to find another side

row.cell: 3. Two sides and the included angle (SAS)
3. Law of Cosines, to find the third side
4. Law of Cosines, to find an angle

note.p: In the ambiguous case, SSA, the Law of Sines is easier to apply, but there will be two possible angles, and we must check each angle to see if it produces a solution. Using the Law of Cosines involves solving a quadratic equation, but each positive solution of the equation yields a solution of the triangle.

sidebyside.p: In the triangle at right, which law should you use to find \angle B ? Which law should you use to find c ?

solution.p: We know two sides of the triangle and the angle opposite one of them. We can use the Law of Sines to find \angle B.
This is the ambiguous case; there are two angles between 0\degree and 180\degree with sine 0.3857, and we must check each angle to see if it produces a solution.
If instead we start by finding side c, we use the Law of Cosines.
You can check that the quadratic equation has only one positive solution for c (or notice that because a \gt b, angle B must be acute).

sidebyside.p: In the triangle at right, which part of the triangle can you find, and which law should you use?

ol.li: No solution
62.8\degree west of north, 344.8 miles
We first find side c using the Law of Cosines
The Law of Sines is not helpful when we know two sides of the triangle and the included angle. In this case we need the Law of Cosines.

assemblage.title: Law of Cosines
assemblage.p: If the angles of a triangle are A, B, and C, and the opposite sides are respectively a, b, and c, then

ol.li: We can also use the Law of Cosines to find an angle when we know all three sides of a triangle.
We can use the Law of Cosines to solve the ambiguous case.

assemblage.title: How to Solve an Oblique Triangle

row.cell: 1. Law of Sines, to find another side

cell.line: 2. Two side and the angle opposite
2. Law of Sines, to find another angle,
or Law of Cosines, to find another side

row.cell: 3. Two sides and the included angle (SAS)
3. Law of Cosines, to find the third side
4. Law of Cosines, to find an angle

ol.li: The Law of Cosines is really a generalization of what familiar theorem?
If you know all three sides of a triangle and one angle, what might be the advantage in using the Law of Cosines o find another angle, instead of the Law of Sines?
State the quadratic formula from memory. Try to sing the quadratic formula to the tune of "Pop Goes the Weasel."
Francine is solving a triangle in which a = 20,~ b = 16, and A = 26\degree. She finds that \sin B = 0.3507. How does she know that B = 20.5\degree, and not 159.5\degree?
